A PLATE WITH TWO PIECES OF APPLE PIE
THE BASE OF THE WAR MEMORIAL,
THE FRONT PAGE OF THE LAWSON JOURNAL-AMERICAN
THE GIRL WITH ALL THE ANSWERS.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER TITLE
dialogues.text: A gigantic aerial shot.  Postwar autos fill the muggy midsummer evening air with the sounds of thousands of HON HORNS, a mere precursor to the traffic yet to come.  Dark outlying neighborhoods are evidence of the postwar home construction boom, as scores of stucco bungalows are bein built in the areas surrounding the beating heart of the t a swath of garishly bright concrete called HOLLYWOOD BOULEVARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, it's not like the postcards say it is.  This is what it's like.  I'm Pete Appleton, and this is my town. Still in the same shot, we rocket down into the center of intersection of Hollywood and Vine, then head west along boulevard, skimming just above the traffic -- past Musso Frank's Grill and the Hollywood Canteen, past the Egyptia Theater and a rumbling Pacific Electric Red Car, across Highland Avenue, past the Paramount Theater, and across t street to GRAUMAN'S CHINESE THEATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Born and raised here, thank you very much.  Sometimes, it seems like everyone here is from somewhere else.  But everyone loves the movies, so Hollywood is everyone's town, and they come here by the busload.  To them, Grauman's Chinese Theater is just about the most exciting place on the planet.  To me, it's the theater that's playing "The African Queen." And like the man said, the film on the marquee is "THE AFRICAN QUEEN."  Still the same shot, buses disgorge TOURISTS, who move into the forecourt of the theater.  Th MEN doff their hats and mop their brows.  The WOMEN pull their blouses away from their chests, fanning themselves movie-star maps as they marvel at the signed cement block We MOVE AMONG THEM, until we pick up A COUPLE, and we sta behind them as they work their way through the crowd, on their way to

dialogues.speaker: THE THEATER ENTRANCE,
dialogues.text: where an ornately attired DOORMAN smiles and tears their tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newsreel's just starting, folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me and my girlfriend.  Her name is Sandra Sinclair, and this is her town, too -- she's from Cleveland.  She came out here to be an actress, and that's just what she's doing.  The first picture I ever wrote, a little potboiler called "Sand Pirates of the Sahara."  Okay, it ain't "Citizen Kane," but you gotta start somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: THE LOBBY
dialogues.text: an explosion of glitz mixed with Chinese myth and legend. Everywhere you look, it's red and orange and plush carpet and golden light.  We MOVE THROUGH the lobby, still in th same shot, still tracking the couple, heading for the auditorium doors, which are swept open by two ramrod-erec USHERS and we move into THE DARKENED THEATER. As the couple, Pete and Sandra, find seats, we HEAR the soundtrack of the film before we see the screen, the unmistakable strains of a march, and then -- still in the same shot -- we see the screen... A NEWSREEL. As the march SWELLS to a crescendo, we HEAR THE NEWSREEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bringing the news of the world to you! Over a newsreel shot of a packed Congressional Committee Hearing Room, a title blares "HOLLYWOOD REDS GO TO JAIL!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four years ago, in one of filmland's darkest hours, ten men, the so-called "Hollywood Ten," were called to testify before the House Committee of Un-American Activities, investigating the proliferation of the dreaded Red Menace in Hollywood. We see several shots of WITNESSES engaged in heated verba battles with congressmen, especially Committee Chairman T JOHNSTON DOYLE and the Majority Counsel, ELVIN CLYDE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Refusing to answer the lawmaker's questions, cowering behind the Fifth Amendment's protection against self-incrimination, the ten motion picture writers dared Congress to come after them.  Well, come after them they did!  And after years of court wrangling, it's now time to pay the piper! Over shots of several of the "Hollywood Ten" being led to jail in handcuffs, the newsreel narration continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, it's off to jail, the charge: Contempt of Congress!  This should give you fellas something to write about now!  A new round of investigations begins this fall, the mandate: Get the reds out of Hollywood! In the audience, one man YELLS "Lock up the commie bastards!," and a few others cheer and laugh.  As the newsreel moves on to a somewhat more innocuous subject, w WHEEL AROUND AND... ENDFRAME ON PETE APPLETON AND SANDRA SINCLAIR. Pete's a handsome fellow in his 30s, and Sandra's a starl pretty girl in her mid-20s.  As she rummages in her purse Pete watches the newsreel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, there's time before the picture starts, you want to get some popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet, honey. Pete kisses Sandra on the cheek, then stands and sprints the aisle to the concession stand, a big unworried grin o his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were young, we were in love, and we were working in pictures.  Life... was good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete pulls up to the guard kiosk in his spiffy yellow convertible Plymouth.  The Guard, RAY, steps out to meet Pete lights up a cigarette.  We get a better sense of him now.  Though earnest, he's jocular, and a bit of a fast talker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very chipper) Mornin', Ray.  Whaddya know whaddya say?  Me and Sandra caught "The African Queen" at the Chinese last night.  Great picture, great picture. Ray is nonplussed.  Tips his hat.  Regards Pete suspiciou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with this "Mr. Appleton" crap?  Your boss hiding in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're clear to go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean? Ray heads back to his kiosk, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant day. Pete, covering his worry well, drives onto the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete pulls up, hops out, grinds out his cigarette, looks around and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete comes down the hall a few steps, stops.  Something's wrong.  It's awfully quiet.  He pokes his head into the d marked "TYPING POOL."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of black Underwoods -- all silent.  The lights in t room are off, and hard shafts of morning sun stream in through the windows.  One typists, LOUISE, is going from machine to machine, pulling covers over them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louise... what gives? She looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Pete... they, uh, they gave everybody the day off... while they sort things out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sort what out?  Are my pages done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took 'em?  Who took 'em?  Louise, what's going on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, I'm not even supposed to be talking to you... She rushes past him.  Pete doesn't quite know what to thi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Peter. Pete turns.  The voice belongs to Pete's agent, LEO KUBEL a rotund man in his fifties.  He wears a perfectly tailor silk suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo... what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROM FAR AWAY, we watch as Leo and Pete come out of the Writer's Building and join a flood of DRESS EXTRAS, all d up in Puritan pilgrim garb and heading for the commissary As they move through the mob and emerge on the other side it's clear that Pete is reeling from something he's just told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, their hands are tied.  You see that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying it's a mistake, that you didn't go to any meetings?  They say you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this "they?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congress, the FBI, Red Channels, it don't matter who the hell "they" is.  "They" know who "they" are, that's all that matters. (deliberately) Now, did you go to any meetings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the spot) No.  Yeah... I... I don't know.  Maybe I did.  Leo, this was before Pearl Harbor.  I was in college.  It was a bunch of kids, and I was just one of 'em.  I didn't believe in what they were saying.  Hell, I didn't even know what they were saying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're saying that it's true.  You went to a meeting of a known communist organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I was trying to impress a skirt.  You know me, I'm non- political.  Republican, Democrat, Communist, there's not a dime's worth of difference between 'em anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should watch what you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who fingered me, but I'm not a communist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, that cuts no ice with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) What?  That I'm accused of being a communist when I don't happen to be one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They know you were at that meeting, Peter.  They've been told, and they know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you're my agent.  Tell "them" to take a flyin' piss.  I didn't do anything wrong.  I fought in the war, for crissakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fought?  Come on, Pete, you ran the PX at Fort Dix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was decorated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  A Purple Heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You broke your arm.  You were coming out of a bar.  You were drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least I was on our side!  Look, they want me to testify?  I'll testify.  I'll tell 'em anything they want to hear!  Jesus, Leo, this is my career!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Leo takes a gold cigarette care from his breast pocket, offers a cigarette to Pete and takes one for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take this personally, kid.  If it were up to me, I'd have you testify wearing your uniform and your medal, wrapped in a flag with one hand on your heart and the other hand on a bible.  What can I say?  I like you. Leo lights Pete's cigarette and his own.  Puts a fatherly hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want you to testify because you're not a big enough fish for them.  They just don't want you writing pictures for now.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Yeah, well, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I believe in you.  More to the point, I read your new script... um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ashes To Ashes?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the one, "Ashes To Ashes."  I think it's great.  But it'll never get made with this communist business hanging over your head.  You can't work until you're cleared -- and believe me, starting right now, I'm gonna do everything I can to make that happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, it is a blacklist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive) Don't say that.  There is no such thing as a blacklist. (calm) Now, are you gonna play ball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Yes. (then, pissed) Leo, goddammit... this isn't fair! Leo blows out a thin stream of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hand on Pete's shoulder) Kid, this is the United States Government we're talkin' about.  Fair ain't the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prominent on the wall is a framed "SAND PIRATES OF THE SAHARA" poster.  Pete reaches up and takes it down.  He l it up against the desk, then sits heavily in the wooden swivel chair.  He swivels around to see

dialogues.speaker: A STUDIO SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: standing by the door.  He's watching Pete's every move. Two boxes sit on the desk, partially packed with Pete's belongings.  Pete lights a cigarette and opens the lower drawer.  He pulls out a stack of scripts and sets them on desk.  He looks at the cover of the first one:

dialogues.speaker: "SAND PIRATES OF THE SAHARA"
dialogues.text: By Peter Appleton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A United Pictures Production February 19, 1951

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete shuffles the scripts and looks at the cover of the second one: "ASHES TO ASHES" By Peter Appleton

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He jams the scripts into one box and turns to the other b which contains somewhat more personal items.  A ragged go pillow with tassels.  Legal pads of notes.  An old tin-to fire truck, its bright red paint chipped and worn.  He tu it around in his hands. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (musing) Huh.  Red... Footsteps approach, and Pete swivels toward the door. SANDRA (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete?  Pete...? Sandra appears in the doorway.  She's in costume -- a Lou XIV courtier.  She bustles past the Guard, rushes to Pete embraces him. SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Pete... They kiss.  The Guard watches their every move. SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly did you hear? SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you got let go. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't alone.  Wasn't Frankie Ruskin directing the picture you're in? SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was, but he got sick.  We got a new director today.  Why? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, whatever Frankie's got, it's catching. SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, he was... let go, too? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, an appeal) They're saying I'm a communist, Sandy.  But I'm not, you know that.  I'm gonna fight 'em, and I'm gonna win, but I'll need your help. During this last, Sandra has been ever-so-slightly pullin away from Pete. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of good people are being accused of things they didn't do.  Hell, even if I was a communist, this is America, goddammit, a person should be able to be whatever they want to be!  Right? Sandra glances at the Guard, who is watching everything. SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Of course, but I... I don't know how I... how much help I can be to you.  This is the sort of thing... someone saying you're a communist... it can ruin your career. Pete sees where this is going.  She's edging toward the d PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you help me, Sandy? SANDRA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to think about this.  I have to get back... I should go... And she's out the door and gone in the blink of an eye. looks at the Guard. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So nice to be a pariah. The Guard turns away.  Pete moves back toward the boxes.  Rummaging again, he comes up with a bottle of Jack Daniel with barely one swig left.  He regards the bottle for a moment, looks to see if the Guard is watching (he isn't), pops the cork, puts it to his lips and drains it.  He loo at it thoughtfully as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HALF-FULL BOTTLE OF JACK DANIELS setting down on a bart

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottle is in front of Pete, who sits at the bar, quie getting stewed.  The Frolic Room is a classic Hollywood d dimly lit and full of character and characters.  It's a q night and getting quieter, as several PATRONS are just leaving, waving goodbye to the bartender, JERRY, early 40 Jerry turns to Pete, eyes him suspiciously from the end o the bar.  Pete picks up the bottle and pours another shot Good boy, he got most of it in the glass. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete.  You think maybe you've had enough? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bought the bottle, didn't I? (raises the shot) To the United States of America.  Long my she wave. He knocks it back and Jerry pours him another. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to light a smoke) Thanks, Jerry.  Tell me something. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tight with J. Edgar Hoover? JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (helps Pete light his cigarette) The G-man? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thickly) Zackly. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, if J. Edgar Hoover walked in here wearing a dress, I wouldn't know him. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad.  He says I'm a communist. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing around) You should watch what you say.  You don't know who's listening. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I'm not a communist, don't you, Jer? JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, I suppose.  That why you're on a bender? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not a bender yet.  This is the start of a bender.  But I can see how you were confused, they look a lot alike. Pete drains his shotglass, puts it back on the bar.  He watches Jerry, who is not about to refill it.  Pete reach for the bottle, but Jerry is faster.   JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete... go home.  Come on, I'll call that girlfriend of yours, what's her name... Sandy? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Sandra Sinclair. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimmee her number, I'll have her pick you up. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra Sinclair.  Wanna know her real name?  Bella Iskowitz.  No one's who they really are, Jer.  Everyone's someone else.  Even you.  Even me.  Especially me.  I'm Peter Appleton, the communist who's not really a communist. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna close up soon.  C'mon, let's call her. Peter stands, stubs out his smoke, drops a few crumpled b on the bar and grabs his hat. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  Can't.  We're through. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I'll call you a cab. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll save you the trouble. (beat) I'm a cab.  There.  Did it myself. Pete's preoccupied with putting on his hat and getting hi car keys out of his coat pocket, a daunting task in his condition. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Sides, car's right outside.  I'll be seein' ya, Jer. JERRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete... And he's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete takes a few steps, stumbles, stops, takes a deep bre then totters briskly towards his car.  He hauls the door and sits inside heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting slumped against the steering wheel, Pete looks as though he could fall asleep right there, which would prob be a good idea. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) Drive.  Drive.  Bad idea.  Too drunk to drive. He looks at his watch. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-thirty.  Huh!  Early.  Can't go home yet. He turns the key and hits the starter.  The engine hums t life.  Pete sits up, opens his eyes wide, shakes off the and puts the car in gear. The Plymouth lurches forward a few yards, screeches to a and stalls. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops. He re-starts the car, puts it in gear, and pulls away and down the deserted boulevard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full moon is low over the ocean.  Pete's car is parke the edge of the sand, the water fifty yards away.  The fe wheel and the roller coaster of the amusement pier are da and eerie silhouettes, lit only by moonlight.  Pete is as in the driver's seat, head tilted back, his hat covering face, snoring. The waves CRASH against the pilings and startle Pete awak PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?  Whatsa... Instantly, he grabs his head. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had no idea how I got to Santa Monica, but it certainly was a good idea.  I don't think I could've faced the headache I had alone in my apartment.  At least I had the ocean air. Pete takes a deep breath... and starts coughing.  He gets his cigarettes and lights up.  He takes a puff and glance his watch. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three forty-five.  I had only been there for a couple of hours at most.  Truth be told, I was still fairly drunk. He starts the car and heads for the highway. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd head north until the sun came up or I ran out of gas, whichever came first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete drives along the moonlit two-lane blacktop.  Waves c to the shore below the roadway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is finally relaxed.  He takes off his hat and jams i down in the back seat.  He takes a deep breath -- with th wind in his hair, a smile grows on his face and he seems peace.  He glances down at the speedometer -- then at the fuel gauge.

dialogues.speaker: FUEL GAUGE
dialogues.text: Pinning on "empty." PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess which came first. He scans the road ahead -- nothing.  Glances to his right

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights of a small town can be seen off in the distanc Pete veers the car off the highway and makes the turn tha will take him toward the lights.  He passes a hand-painte sign that gives him hope: "GAS - 1 MI."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's car rolls up and stops.  There's a light on the si and another in the station's window, but the place is deserted. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've known better than to think that a service station in the sticks would be open at this hour, but it wasn't like I had a lot of choices. Pete looks ahead toward the town.  Its few lights twinkle the distance. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell.  At least there'd be a diner opening in a couple of hours.  I'd get some pie and coffee, and then I could worry about the gas. Pete pulls out onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's car trundles along, blowing past a hand-painted roadside sign which reads:

dialogues.speaker: NARROW BRIDGE
dialogues.text: USE CAUTION!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete's headlights catch a glimpse of another sign, readin "LAWSON WASH," just in front of a small wooden auto bridg Barely reducing his speed, Pete heads onto the bridge...

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD
dialogues.text: ... his headlights pick up the glowing eyes of a hapless possum... Pete swerves to avoid the animal, and a wheel drops off t edge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and the Plymouth careens over the side of the bridge into the rapidly-moving water below!

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The water is flowing very quickly, and the current is intense.  Pete pulls himself out of the driver's seat (thankfully, it's a convertible) and swims over the windshield. But... his left sleeve is caught on the door handle.  Nea out of breath and panicking, Pete shucks off the jacket a heads for the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete breaks the surface and gasps for air.  His fight isn over yet, as the current is pulling him rapidly downstrea He swims with all his might toward the far bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drained, Pete pulls himself out of the water and staggers his feet. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) Oh my god!  I don't believe... oh my god... He stumbles along backwards a couple of steps... and his hits a rock... Pete falls backward -- and his head strikes a glancing bl on another rock.  He rolls down the bank, unconscious, an lands face down in the mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN BLACK, we slowly become aware of a panting, breathing sound -- the sound of a dog...

dialogues.speaker: ON A DOG'S FACE
dialogues.text: A yellow labrador, full frame.  It takes a couple more sniffs, then starts licking furiously. OLD MAN'S VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie, whatcha got there?  Huh, girl?  Whatcha find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is still laying face down on the bank, being fervent licked in the face by the dog.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OLD MAN
dialogues.text: A no-nonsense sort in his late-60s, he wears overalls and old railroad cap.  He comes down to Pete, and using his walking stick, pokes him in the side. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, who are ya?  my dog likes you, but that don't mean much, she likes skunks, too.  Sweet n'stupid, that's why I keep her. Pete blinks up at the Old Man, his mouth gaping open. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, you okay?  You look wet.  You in an accident or somethin'? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know. He sits up, and the Old Man gets a look at his head, whic caked with mud and blood on one side. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You best come with me.  Can ya walk? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... yes, I think so. He stands up shakily.  The Old Man gives Pete a hand. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'll have the Doc look you over. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My head hurts. OLD MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't be surprises.  You smell like that was quite a night before you had there. (to the dog) Maggie!  Let's go now! And they head toward the road to town.  BOOMING UP, we SE them pass a roadside sign:

dialogues.speaker: ON THE SIGN
dialogues.text: WELCOME TO LAWSON, CALIFORNIA EST. 1869 ELEV. 275    POP. 1755

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THAT GAVE ITS ALL OLD MAN (STANTON)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name's Stanton Lawson.  My ancestors founded this town. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ancestors? STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, my grandpap.  But "ancestors" sounds better, don't it? (hands Pete a handkerchief) Here. Pete takes the handkerchief and wipes the mud and some of blood off his face. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose.  Thanks. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look familiar, fella.  What's your name? Pete stops, thinks for a moment. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I... I honestly don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Stanton walk along Commerce Street, the main dra through the center of the small town.  Lawson is a bit ru down, creeping inexorably toward decrepit.  Despite that, there's a timeless quality to the small buildings, a fami All-American feel. Several of the PEOPLE walking along the street take notic Pete and nod to Stanton, who nods back. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all know you? STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course they all know me.  And I know all them.  Town's got my name, don't it? They pass the window of the drug store, COLE'S PHARMACY.  Pete looks down and sees

dialogues.speaker: TWO FADED GOLD STARS
dialogues.text: in the window with two faded photos, all decked in tatter black crepe.  Two boys, no more than 18 and 19, who went to war and didn't come back. Stanton notes Pete stopping to look at the stars and phot STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie Cole here just got himself elected mayor.  Lost both his boys in the war.  Kenny at Anzio and Willie at Normandy. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) The war... STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points across the street) Mabel over there at the diner lost her husband Max.  Okinawa, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL'S DINER
dialogues.text: A typical small-town greasy spoon -- with one faded star prominent in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On MABEL LANIER, a sweet-faced woman in her 30s.  She sta vacantly into space, her reverie broken by a customer nee a coffee refill. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All told, this little town gave sixty-two of its finest to the war.  Seventeen of 'em at Normandy alone.  More'n its share, I should say.  Got us a letter from President Truman.  City council commissioned a war memorial.  Been sittin' in the basement of city hall these six years.  Town never had the heart to put it up.  Place just hasn't been the same since the war.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON AND PETE
dialogues.text: Pete looks longingly toward the diner.  Stanton takes not STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hungry, son? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Very. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any money? Pete rummages in his pants pockets, and comes up with thr quarters. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six bits.  More'n enough to buy some breakfast.  C'mon. And they head across the street.

dialogues.speaker: A PLATE WITH TWO PIECES OF APPLE PIE
dialogues.text: A fork comes into frame and tears into one of the slices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is fairly shoveling the pie into his mouth, pausing to wash it down with gulps of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: MABEL
dialogues.text: stands nearby, watching in amazement as her pie is consum in record time. Pete notices that Stanton and Mabel -- and the other PATR for that matter -- are watching his feeding frenzy.  He s in his tracks, and starts chewing leisurely.  He smiles a Mabel. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Pie's... good. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Like you could tell. (to Stanton) Where'd you find him? STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down by the wash. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta put a rail on that thing before someone else gets killed. (to Pete) Three people have died there, Mister.  You're lucky to be alive. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (draining the coffee cup) Thanks.  More coffee? Mabel obliges.  As she pours the coffee, she looks at Pet MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you look familiar.  You ever been in here before? Pete shakes his head. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't remember who he is, Mabel.  Gonna take him to the Doc, as soon as he gets in. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distractedly) Doc should be in for his coffee and bear claw any minute... (to Pete) You sure you never been in here? Pete looks up at Mabel and smiles winningly. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd remember this pie. Mabel, thoroughly charmed, smiles back at Pete. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patting his hand) I'll just get you another piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stoop-shouldered little man in his late 60s, HARRY TRUM shambles along the street, headed for Mabel's Diner.  The a sadness about Harry, the world-weary melancholy of a ma who has little to smile about because he has little to ca about.  After a couple of steps, he's met up by DOC BEN LARDNER, a vigorous man in his 50s.  He comes up behind H and claps him on the back. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Mornin' Harry.  Fine day, isn't it? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Doc.  Yes, yes it looks just fine. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty to do today? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Oh, yes, plenty.  Plenty. They're at the door of the diner.  Doc opens it for Harry LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner comes over to Mabel, who hands him a tall paper c of coffee and bags him a bear claw. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin' Mabel, Stan. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin' Doc.  Got some new business for you today. Lardner and Pete make eye contact, and the doctor notices bump on his head. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, son.  How'd that happen? STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't know.  And he don't know his name, neither.  Found him down by the wash. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better come with me, son. (to Mabel, indicating the coffee and danish) On my tab? MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. Lardner, Stanton and Pete rise and move to the door.  Pet turns back, takes the three quarters out of his pocket, a puts them on the counter, smiling brightly at Mabel. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Great pie. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (blushing) You're welcome.  Come again.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY
dialogues.text: seated at the opposite end of the counter.  He glances up Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Pete smiles at Mabel and turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: ON HARRY
dialogues.text: His mouth falls open, his hand moves to cover it.  He's j seen a ghost... HARRY'S POV - SLOW MOTION... ... as the three men pass by the diner's window.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wide eyed) Sweet Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: A FINGER --
dialogues.text: moving left-to-right, right-to-left through space. LARDNER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow my finger.  Just use your eyes.  That's it.  Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Lardner is checking Pete's eyes.  Pete sits on an examination table, his shirt off, his head freshly bandag Stanton lurks in the corner, Maggie curled at his feet. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was passed out cold.  Maggie woke 'im. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  He looks familiar. (to Pete) Open your mouth.  Say "ah." Pete does.  Lardner has a look as Stanton pulls out a poc watch. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said as much myself, Doc.  Can't place him, though.  To look at him, you'd think the cheese slid off his cracker. (looks at his watch) Well, morning's half-over.  I'm off. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. Lawson. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.  Whoever-you-are. Stanton and Maggie exit.  Lardner checks Pete's ears. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any idea how you got here, son? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. Lardner sniffs him. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been drinkin' a bit, have we? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.  I guess so.  Smells like it. (smacks his lips and frowns) Tastes like it. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've been wet to the skin.  You must've fallen in. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess I did. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky you got out, that water's got quite a pull, and it empties straight into the ocean. Lardner takes a shirt off his counter and hands it to Pet LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, one of mine. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Pete puts on the shirt. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember if you were driving a car?  Maybe you went over the bridge.  No guard rail there, it's easy to do.  It's happened before. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible.  I just don't remember. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you don't know your name or who you are, that right? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frustrated) I... no, I... I just can't... LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) It's okay, son.  We just need to call you something.  That's all. Pete stifles a laugh. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me... Ishmael? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least you remember "Moby Dick."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner is on the phone, sipping his coffee and nibbling bear claw.  Pete is standing, nosing around the office -- diplomas, photographs, knick-knacks.  He zeros in on one photo in particular.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE PHOTO
dialogues.text: one of Lardner and a beautiful YOUNG WOMAN.  They've been fishing, and the young woman displays a much larger catch than Lardner. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Stanton found him by the wash.  Not hurt too bad, but he took a nasty bump on the head and he can't remember who he is.  We both think he looks familiar, but we can't place him.  You bet.  He'll be here. Lardner hangs up and watches Pete looking at the pictures LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's me and my daughter Adele.  My pride and joy.  Charms the fish right out of the lake, she does. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's very pretty. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Well, Sheriff's on his way over, and maybe we can get to the bottom of who you are... Lardner stares at him.  Pete takes note, turns toward him LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... sorry 'bout that, but you do look familiar to me. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wish I could say the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sheriff's sedan pulls up to the office and SHERIFF CE ELDRIDGE, 45, gets out.  As he gets a few steps from the door, Harry Trumbo jumps out from around the side of the building and stops him. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Cecil!  Cecil, there's a young man in there... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled) Lord love a duck, Harry, you wanna give me a heart attack right in front of the doctor's office? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me!  The young man in there... Eldridge keeps moving to the door. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Stan Lawson found him unconscious by the wash this morning, and I'm here to investigate, and if we find anything interesting, it'll be in the paper, so why don't you just... Harry jumps in front of Eldridge and grabs him by the shoulders. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cecil, listen to me! The sheriff stops. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless) It's Luke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Eldridge is seated across from Pete.  He's starin him intently.  Silence. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wallet, huh? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No identification at all. (beat) What're you thinkin', Cecil? ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm thinkin' is we got us one a'two things here.  A mystery or a damn miracle.  And by god I can't tell which. (to Pete) Boy, you say you have no idea who you are?  That right? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever been in this town before, to your knowledge? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this place sorta reminds me of something. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It's a Wonderful Life." ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jimmy Stewart picture?  I remember that one.  Saw it over at the Bijou.  So, you remember that, huh? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It's a Wonderful Life?" ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the Bijou.  Either one. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember the picture... but I don't remember where I saw it. The Sheriff rises and crosses to the door. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc, with your permission, I want to bring someone in here.  Maybe it'll jar this young man's memory. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By all means. Eldridge opens the door. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to someone offscreen) Harry, why don't you come on in here. Harry enters the office, doffs his hat, revealing a full of snow-white hair.  He nods to Eldridge and Lardner, and slowly turns to face Pete.  He looks closer... and closer Hesitantly, he takes a couple of steps towards Pete, who slowly rises out of his chair to meet the old man's gaze. Finally, they're standing practically toe-to-toe.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: looks a bit puzzled, but the old man has such a sweet fac

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: has tears forming in his eyes.  A smile turns up the corn of his mouth, and quickly lights up his whole face. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly, to Eldridge) Are you saying that he's... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling broadly) Shhhhhh. Harry takes Pete in his arms and hugs him tightly, buryin his face in Pete's shoulder and sobbing. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew all along.  I knew you were alive!  Oh, Luke... Pete doesn't quite know what to think.  He clearly has no idea who this old man is. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouth agape in disbelief) Mother o'god... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Pete) Give the man a hug, boy!  That's your father! Pete looks at Harry.  It's not so much that he remembers anything -- he's swept up in the moment. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father...? Pete wraps his arms around Harry and hugs him tightly, glancing over at

dialogues.speaker: ELDRIDGE AND LARDNER
dialogues.text: who look on goofily, fighting back tears.  They smile at Pete, who smiles back tentatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, Pete, Eldridge and Lardner come outside. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I'll give you two a lift back to the Bijou. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bijou? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you live. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We live in a theater? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one in town. (he opens the car door for Pete) Get in, son. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Lardner) Ben, when's Delly due back? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Tomorrow afternoon... (seized by a thought) ... oh my god... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Exactly.  Break it to her gently. Eldridge and Harry get in the car.  Lardner comes over to Pete's back seat window. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get plenty of rest, Luke.  You took a pretty big wallop there. He turns to move away, then turns back. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to have you back. Eldridge starts the car and they drive away. (NOTE: Henceforth, "PETE" will be known as "LUKE."  It'll easier to keep track of things, since everyone's now call him Luke, anyway.  Trust me.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry sits next to the Sheriff, and Luke has the back sea all to himself.  He leans forward toward the front seat a taps Harry on the shoulder. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me... what's your, um, your name? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, son.  Harry. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... what's my name again? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert Lucas Trumbo.  But you've been "Luke" since you were a baby. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. (taking it for a spin) Luke.  Luke.  I like it. Luke looks at the town as they drive down Commerce Street

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shops are open for business, TOWNSPEOPLE are going about their lives.  A few stop and watch as the Sheriff's car g by. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I been gone? Eldridge looks at Harry, who stares ahead. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long? Pause.  The silence is too thick, and Harry has to answer He turns around in his seat and faces Luke. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently) You never came back from the war.  We were told you were missing and presumed dead. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I leave? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joined up one month to the day after Pearl Harbor.  January seventh... nineteen forty-two. Luke sits back against the back seat and lets this sink i HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine and-a-half years ago. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine and-a-half years... ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comin' up on the Bijou, gents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eldridge's car rounds the corner, pulls up and stops. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we are. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, son, you're home! Luke peers across the street... his mouth gapes open... HIS POV - THE BIJOU. The Bijou is a decaying, Dada-esque, grab-bag of building styles.  It's as though the architect took random parts o Chinese temple, a Mosque, a Pagoda, a Sphinx, a symphony and a slaughterhouse, put them in a bag, gave it a good shake, tossed the contents out onto a blueprint and promp built the result. As a matter of fact, if you didn't know that the place wa "The Bijou," you'd probably wonder what the cryptic messa " HE B J U"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: was trying to convey from atop the crumbling parapet. And now, the reason for the deteriorated state of the " H J U" sign becomes apparent.  Train tracks run right behin the building on an elevated trestle.  As we watch, a TRAI ROARS BY.  Everything shakes.  It's not an earthquake, it trainquake.  The "J" teeters at a jaunty angle, threateni to dislodge and tumble down to join its fallen brothers.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: stares at the monstrosity.  His face is ashen.  His heart sunk to somewhere below his knees. The Bijou. Harry jumps out of the car excitedly. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the lift, Cecil. ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.  Welcome home, Luke. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint smile) Thanks. Luke opens the back door and slowly steps out.  Harry gra his arm and pulls a ring of keys from his pocket. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait'll you see the inside! LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior of the theater fulfills every promise made b the exterior.  Moth-eaten velvet-flocked wallpaper hangs shards and pieces from the walls.  It's sort of a cross between a gaudy cathouse and a mausoleum, served up with generous helpings of dust and grime, an almost unbeatable combination of questionable taste and neglect. Above the center of the lobby hangs what was -- and is -- probably the only truly beautiful item in the whole theater -- A DELICATE CRYSTAL CHANDELIER. Even under a veneer of dust, the fragile droplets of cut crystal seem to pick up every available point of light an scatter it in a hundred directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Harry standing below.  Luke is lost in a gulf somewhere between surprise and disgust. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been closed for a while. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling wanly) Ah. Luke walks toward the auditorium doors and slowly, cracks open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ocean of two hundred or so seats on the main floor se to be, for the most part, intact -- although the occasion row seems to have loosed itself from its moorings and hea itself up against the row behind or in front.

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: is really not much more than a tatty bit of yellowing mus framed by ragged red velveteen drapery. In the tiny orchestra pit, as we will see later, is an ol upright piano. Luke walks a few steps down the aisle.  He picks a seat o the aisle near the middle of the theater and sits.  As he does, a CAT, an orange tabby, leaps out from under anothe seat, jets past Luke and disappears down the aisle and backstage.  Harry comes over and sits behind him. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Harry) Exactly how long has the Bijou been closed? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmmm... after you left, it was difficult, and then Lily -- that's your mother -- she took ill and died... we haven't shown a picture since forty-eight. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deep breath) Well, after the war, with so many of the town's boys killed, people around here didn't much feel like going to the movies, I guess.  Some of 'em moved away -- Los Angeles, Sacramento, San Francisco.  Wasn't much to keep 'em here, I expect.  And now with this "television" thing -- people just aren't going out as much as they used to. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you have any help? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I had Irene and Old Tim but they really couldn't help much.  Broke their hearts when we closed up.  Broke mine, too. (brightening) But now that you're back, well, things will be different around here, that's for sure. (rises, grabs Luke's arm) C'mon, I'll show you where we live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small apartment above the projection booth is quite a contrast to the rest of the theater.  It's neat as a pin, fairly lit, as Harry has just pulled back the curtains, allowing the sun to flood the room. A beam of golden light falls across a table, atop which a SEVERAL FRAMED PHOTOS. One of the photos is of the real, much-younger Luke.  It' Norman Rockwell scene, at a train depot, with an army-iss olive drab duffel bag slung over his shoulder.  He has on arm around Harry and the other around his mother. (And by the way, Pete's resemblance to the real Luke -- e in a nearly 10 year old photo -- is pretty damn startling HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day you shipped out.  That was a proud day for your mother and me.  Last time you saw her.  Last time I saw you. He smiles. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till today. Luke sets it down and picks up another photo, that of a f looking woman.  It's a formal portrait, dating perhaps fr the 30's. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Lily.  Your mother, rest her soul. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (repeating) Mother. (to Harry) She's beautiful. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming over) Well, yes, that she was.  She certainly made this place a home. He takes the picture from Luke, kisses it, and gently replaces it on the table.  Luke goes over to the sofa and sits. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Can I get you anything?  I can put some coffee on or some... Harry looks at Luke, who has almost instantly fallen asle on the sofa. He goes to him, gently picks his feet off the floor, lift them onto the sofa.  Removes his shoes, sets them on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: A BLANKET
dialogues.text: being drawn up Luke's chest.

dialogues.speaker: HARRY
dialogues.text: stands, looks down warmly at his son.  Then, suddenly, he seized by a thought.  He turns and crosses to the window.

dialogues.speaker: THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: There's a small picture frame in the window.  Harry reach down, gingerly picks it up and turns it around.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FRAME
dialogues.text: It's a single, faded gold star.  One war casualty. Harry clutches it to his chest, looks over at the sleepin Luke and smiles. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) When I woke up this morning, my son was dead.  Now, I have my boy again. (closes his eyes) I have my boy again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early morning.  Luke is sound asleep, still in his clothes.  In the distance, a train sounds its HORN. Luke rolls over on his back, still asleep, snoring lightl Slowly, he starts to wake up, eyes still closed. Something's strange, though.  He frowns.  The train is GETTING CLOSER.  Luke's eyes POP OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the train RUMBLES BY, shaking everything in the room, looks up to see three ancient cherubs staring down at him Harry, an elderly WOMAN, and an elderly BLACK MAN. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) 'Morning, Son. ELDERLY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Good morning, Luke. ELDERLY BLACK MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no expression) 'Mornin'. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well? Luke is speechless.  It he dreaming this? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They couldn't wait to see you. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who... are they? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the staff of the Bijou. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  What... what time is it? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six-thirty.  I thought we'd get an early start. Luke sits up on the sofa and tries to get a little more awake.  He rubs the side of his head that is still bandag The elderly woman nudges Harry gently. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry, they know you, but you don't... you need to be re- introduced.  Luke, this is Mrs. Irene Terwilliger. Luke stands and shakes MRS. TERWILLIGER'S hand.  She's ti seventy if she's a day.  She smiles and curtsies slightly Her eyes sparkle brightly, her manner almost coquettish. MRS. TERWILLIGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Head cashier and refreshments clerk.  So glad to have you back, my boy! (to Harry) Much more handsome than I remember him. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this fine fellow is our head usher, resident fix-it man and custodian.  Luke, meet Old Tim. (to Old Tim) You remember Luke, don't you? OLT TIM is -- well, old.  His clothes are a tad shabby, b well maintained, though they hang loosely on his gangly frame.  He wears an old blue knit cap, which he quickly removes as he shakes Luke's hand.  He's a man of few word his manner is painfully shy -- and he never smiles. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a young Tim? OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, why do they call you "Old Tim?" Pause. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm old. Harry steps forward, takes Luke's arm. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, lots to do, so we'd better get a move on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, Harry and Mrs. Terwilliger walk down the aisle towa the screen.  Old Time lags a few steps behind.  At the orchestra pit, Harry climbs the steps, crosses the pit. screen is a sea of repair patches.  Harry pats it.  Dust flies. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Fraid this has seen better days.  Well, I was meaning to get a new screen, anyway. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I n-need me a new uniform. Luke looks at Old Tim, then at Harry. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Luke) I promised him a new uniform when we re-opened. (to Old Tim) And you'll get one, too. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I hate to bring this up, but screens and uniforms and paint and repairs are going to take money, which I'm willing to bet none of us has. Silence from the group. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so. Beat.  Harry brightens, clambers down the steps and races the aisle. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone want to see the projector?

dialogues.speaker: TWO CARBON ARCS
dialogues.text: are squeakily being cranked together above the din of a f motor.  A puff of smoke, then -- BZZZZZZZZZTT -- LIGHT. metal door is closed over the arcs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry dances around to the other side of the projector an adjusts the focus on the beam of light.  The others look as he gazes at the screen through the tiny window. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.  Bright and even from edge to edge.  See for yourself. The carbons sputter and die.  The light flickers out.  Ha is crestfallen, turns off the motor. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's always been a bit tricky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Terwilliger is dusting the concession stand with a ragged feather duster, a hopeless task.  Old Tim is on a rickety ladder, replacing burned-out bulbs in the chandel The orange tabby cat scratches itself on the leg of the ladder. Old Tim climbs down and catches his breath.  Mrs. Terwill sneezes. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless. MRS. TERWILLIGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Timothy. They both stop their work and glance warily at the door marked "OFFICE." MRS. TERWILLIGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) What do you suppose they're talking about? OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunno.  Boy's smart. MRS. TERWILLIGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightly) Yes, he seems to be. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke is poring over the ledger books, adding up figures o old manual adding machine. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... Harry?  Did I ever keep the books here? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, your mother did, then I did after she passed. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm the first one to admit that I don't know anything about bookkeeping, but there are some very interesting things in here. He scans down a page. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "February 10, 1942.  Picture 'Ball of Fire.'" HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appreciatively) Gary Cooper.  And Barbara Stanwyck.  Yowsa. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) "Eight p.m. showtime, ninety-six admissions, receipts including concessions, $84.75... plus one fryer and two-dozen eggs." He closes the book and looks expectantly at Harry. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "one fryer and two-dozen eggs?" HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-two was a lean year around here.  The war had just started... you were gone less than a month... and we were coming off a bit of a drought as I recall.  Not everyone could ante up the price of a ticket, and a chicken's as good as money if you ask me.  At that time, it meant a lot to the folks around here to be able to come to the pictures. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, but poultry...? HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rhapsodically) I know it's hard to believe, son, but this place, this little place this wasn't a theater then, this was a palace!  Any man, woman, child, you, me, it didn't matter, you bought your ticket and you walked in and you... Harry puts his hand on his chest and sighs. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you were in a palace.  It was like a dream.  It was like heaven, like you died and went to a palace in heaven, that's what it was like.  And spotless, too. Inspired, Harry stands, takes Luke by the arm. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me! He drags him out of the office and into the lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim watch as Harry leads Luke through the lobby. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Maybe you had problems and worries out there, but once you came through that door, they didn't matter anymore.  In here, you were safe.  Maybe it was just an escape from reality, but... oh, god... it was beautiful. Harry leads Luke into the auditorium.  The car follows, b Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim stay behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry trots down the aisle and looks up at the screen. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exuberant) Charlie Chaplin.  Keaton and Lloyd.  Swanson.  And later on, Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert and Jimmy Stewart and James Cagney and Bogart and Becall and Judy and Mickey... and Fred and Ginger. He turns to Luke. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) They... were... like... gods! He points to the screen. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that... was the altar.  Would you remember if I told you, we felt lucky to be here, to have the privilege of watching them? (sadly) This television thing.  Why would you want to sit at home and watch a little box with a little screen?  Because it's convenient?  Because you don't have to get dressed and put on a coat and a tie and a hat?  Because you can just... sit there?  How can you call that "entertainment," all alone in your living room?  Where are the other people?  Where's the audience? Harry comes over to Luke. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Where's the magic? He stands behind Luke and whispers in his ear. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you.  In a place like this, the magic is all around you.  All the time.  Everywhere.  In every thing. He turns Luke around and looks him in the eye. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trick... is to see it. Pause. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I... HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, I think you loved the Bijou even more than I did.  You've got to remember that.  You've got to. Still looking at Luke, Harry takes a step back, then slow walks up the aisle, disappearing into the lobby. Luke walks down the aisle.  At the edge of the orchestra he stands looking up at the screen.  The orange tabby cat MEOWS, and Luke glances toward it, standing onstage by th edge of the screen.  They exchange looks as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doc Lardner is seated in an easy chair, his feet up, read Life magazine.  The radio is on, and Patti Page is singin "The Tennessee Waltz." There's a noise offscreen, and Lardner looks up.  In the entrance hall, the front door opens.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE "DELLY" LARDNER
dialogues.text: enters.  She's a strikingly beautiful woman in her late 2 She takes off a felt cap, and her long, auburn hair casca down. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delly?  In here. Lardner rises as Adele comes into the living room.  They embrace warmly. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd it go? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as bad as I thought it would.  I think I passed. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kisses her forehead) That's my girl! (he hugs her again) Did you...? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hiccups, which was good.  Who wants an attorney who gets the hiccups when she gets nervous? ("serious" lawyer voice) "Your (hic!) honor, I (hic!) object!" They laugh. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always told you, baby... (taps her head) ... it's all up here. Lardner gives her an extra squeeze, continues to hold ont her just a bit too long.  Adele detects something amiss. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?  What is it? Beat. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's... Adele breaks away from him. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extreme concern) Oh my god... who died?

dialogues.speaker: A GLASS OF WATER
dialogues.text: on a kitchen table.  Offscreen, we HEAR A HICCUP.  Then another.  Adele's hand reaches into frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lardner stands over Adele, who is seated at the table, holding the glass of water. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink slowly. She raises the glass to her lips. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the other side of the glass. It's a particularly gymnastic way in which to drink water but Adele accomplishes it with aplomb.  She waits for a moment -- then hiccups again. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think (hic!) it's worse (hic!) now. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That always used to work. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well it's not everyday you get (hic!) news like this.  You're sure he's (hic!) okay?  Other than the (hic!) bump on the head? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hedging) Well... ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hic!) Dad... (hic!) Lardner sits at the table and takes Adele's hand. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't remember anything, Delly.  Doesn't know how he got here, doesn't remember his father, the town, the Bijou, anyone... ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... including me.  Right?  (hic!) LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not.  He looked right at your picture without batting an eye.  But it's probably temporary.  He got all the way to Lawson, so he clearly knew who he was and what he was doing until he hit his head.  I'm sure it'll all come back to him.  It just takes a catalyst. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, (hic!) me? LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible. Off Adele's thoughtful hiccuping, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke and Harry, walking along, make a turn onto Commerce Street, heading for Mabel's.  It's still light out, and a soft breeze skitters some leaves along the sidewalk. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take breakfast and supper at Mabel's every day except Sunday.  Have for years, since Lily died.  If it weren't for Mabel, I'd probably starve to death. ERNIE COLE, a slight, balding man in his 50s, is locking door of his pharmacy across the street, when he spots Har and Luke. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry!  Hold on a second! Ernie runs across the street and, slightly winded, stands before Luke, staring.  Luke shoots a glance at Harry, who taps Ernie on the shoulder. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really him, Ernie. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agape) Well, I'll be... He sticks his hand out and Luke takes it.  Ernie pumps it enthusiastically. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By god, Luke, if it isn't good to see you again. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (uncertain) Uh, thanks.  Good to see you again, too, uh... HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ernie. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Ernie. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still at a lose) Well, I'll be... HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just gonna get some supper.  Would you like to join us? ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would I ever! The three walk toward the diner, but before they get two steps, they hear: WOMAN'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Luke Trumbo? They turn to see a stout woman, KATIE RUTHERFORD, 40s, rushing toward them.  She rushes right into a very surpri Luke's arms and hugs him tightly. KATIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Luke, it's so good to have you back! HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie, would you like to join us for dinner?  The more, the merrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diner is packed.  In addition to Ernie and Katie, MEN WOMEN and CHILDREN occupy every seat and table, and many are standing, even hanging out the door. At the focus of the crowd are Luke and Harry, seated at t counter.  Harry is leisurely eating a chicken dinner, whi Luke is working on a steak.  A young man seated at the opposite side of the counter is speaking.  He's CARL LEFF 30s. CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eagerly) Hey, Luke, remember the time you and me, we was playing with firecrackers and the one you was lighting blew up too soon and singed all the hair offa my head? A few people shake their heads, smile and laugh. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, no.  What happened? CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deflated) Well... um, all the hair got singed offa my head.  It was pretty funny. A couple of TITTERS are heard. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even my eyebrows.  But they grew back. Luke leans toward Harry, who never looks up from his chic HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl.  Friend of yours from high school.  Everybody calls him "Cueball." LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Oh, hi Cue... Carl.  Sorry. CARL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brightening) Oh, heck, that's all right.  It's just good to have you back.  Isn't that right, Bob?  Hey, Luke, you remember my brother Bob?  You two joined up the same day. Luke smiles and nods at the young man sitting next to Car

dialogues.speaker: BOB LEFFERT
dialogues.text: is a good-looking fellow, a few years older than Carl.  H face is pale and downcast, and he wears a cap pulled down his forehead.  He looks up at Luke with hollow eyes.  Bri his right hand up, pushes the brim of his cap up.  Except there's no hand there -- it's a hook. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Hey, Bob.  Good to meet you. Bob doesn't react.  He glances away, and for a moment, hi eyes meet Mabel's.  She smiles warmly.  He turns away. Ernie Cole pipes up. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke, I know there's a question that's on everybody's mind. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now that you're back, what're your plans? All eyes on Luke.  He freezes, having just taken a forkfu food in his mouth.  Harry jumps in. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gonna re-open the Bijou, that's what. A MURMUR goes through the crowd.  Stanton Lawson, standin behind Luke, taps him on the shoulder. STANTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That true? LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the spot) Well... we're gonna try. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of work, son.  Place's been closed, what, three, four years now.  Gonna be tough. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's tough, that means it's worth doing. Someone shouts "That's the spirit!," another shouts "Hear hear!," and a chorus of VOICES join in agreement. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where's Spencer Wyatt? SPENCER'S VOICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, back here, Mr. Mayor. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, come on out here so's we can see you. SPENCER WYATT steps around from the back of the crowd nea the door.  He's a tall, dark-haired, gangly, bespectacled kid, no more than 19 or 20.  Painfully shy, he clutches a clarinet case to his chest.  He timidly smiles and waves Luke, who smiles and nods back. SPENCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Luke. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Spencer. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spence, that band of yours -- you think they're ready to play? (to Luke) Spencer and his pals went ahead and got together a good ol' big band. SPENCER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been practicing... uh, sure, I guess. ERNIE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, how about tomorrow night, eight p.m., in city hall square?  What I'm proposin' is a "Welcome Home Luke" celebration. Vociferous general AGREEMENT from the crowd -- which is quickly quieted by a MURMUR, which starts at the front do The crowd parts and grow silent, revealing a woman standi in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: She locks eyes with Luke.  Her hand goes to her mouth and eyes well up.  Slowly, she moves around the counter, the crowd moving aside for her. She stands in front of Luke, who has stood up to meet her Her eyes moist, she looks up at him. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you... remember me? LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen you before.  Your picture... Mabel, clutching a napkin, leans over to Katie. MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Look! LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but I don't think I remember you. Adele leans up and kisses him softly.  He looks at her. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll sure try. As Mabel and Katie dab at their eyes, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele and Luke stroll down the street side by side.  She looks at him for a long moment. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... I just wondering where you've been all this time. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look... different. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little.  I think you grew an inch or so.  And you've lost weight. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did?  Huh! Tentatively, she takes his hand and holds it.  From behin them, we HEAR A SHUFFLING SOUND.  Adele turns...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping a discreet distance, EVERYONE from the diner is following them.  Adele turns and addresses the crowd. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the group) You can all go home, now.  He's not going anywhere. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on home, folks.  And thanks for the welcome. Harry comes over. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be home in a little while, Harry.  Don't wait up. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two have a lot of catching up to do, I guess. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet. HARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, son. (tips his hat) 'Night, Delly. And the rest of the crowd disperses, variously wishing th pair goodnight.  Luke and Adele watch them disperse. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.  We're alone. They turn and start walking. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do I feel like we're still being shadowed? LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... where can we go? Adele brightens. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a place.  Come on! She grabs his hand and they run toward the town square.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele and Luke stand by the front steps. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: City hall? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must not remember anything.  Come on. She grabs his hand and they run to the side of the buildi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele and Luke stand by a basement window, inches off the ground.  She looks around.  Certain the coast is clear, s pounds on the window in three "special" places, and it po up and open.  She looks at Luke. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You first. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a gentleman.  You have to help me down.

dialogues.speaker: A LARGE, MUSLIN-COVERED OBJECT.
dialogues.text: Slowly, the muslin is drawn off, revealing A STATUE OF A KNEELING SOLIDER, praying before a soldier's grave.  We slowly PAN DOWN from the top of the statue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ADELE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we were kids, my Dad was mayor, and you and me and a bunch of others used to come down here all the time.

dialogues.speaker: ON ADELE AND LUKE
dialogues.text: looking up at the statue in this city hall basement stora room, lit only by a single shaft of moonlight from the window.  The muslin covering lay bunched at their feet. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, there was a lot more room before they stuck the memorial down here. LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at the door) How'd they get it inside? ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the door.  It comes apart. She moves to the memorial.  Squinting, she examines its b ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name's on here.  See? Luke comes over.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BASE OF THE MEMORIAL
dialogues.text: ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
