dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the country Luke fought for. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lest we forget, Peter, your own military career was somewhat less illustrious than Luke's. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wrong, Leo. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, don't let that stop you all of a sudden. Leo pulls a folded paper from his coat pocket and hands i Pete. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  When you're called, read this to them.  Just tell the bastards what they want to hear, and we can all get on with our lives. There's a knock at the door.  Leo opens it.  Standing the is a small MAN wearing a serious suit and an even more serious fedora. THE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Appleton? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) You found him. The Man reaches into his breast pocket and withdraws a bl backed folded document, which he hands to Pete.  As he do a FLASH lights the room. At the door, a pair of PHOTOGRAPHERS and a NEWSREEL CAMER are jockeying for position.  Pete rolls his eyes. THE MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Appleton, you are hereby subpoenaed to appear as a witness before a special session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.  You are to appear in Los Angeles, California, at the Biltmore Hotel, at the date and time specified herein. Pete takes the subpoena.  There's an awkward moment, as t newsreel camera is still rolling.  Pete cradles the subpo like an Oscar statuette and smiles into the lens. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ("on") This is a great honor.  I'll treasure this always.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUBPOENA
dialogues.text: in a partially-packed suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete is sitting in a chair, reading the statement Leo gav him. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby renounce my membership in the American Communist Party, and by way of purging myself of my indiscretion, wish to provide the following names of fellow members to this committee, so that those persons may have the opportunity to do as I have done..." He scans down the page.  It's a long list. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... He HEARS a "meow!" And turns to look.

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: is standing in the bedroom doorway.  He folds up and pock the list. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Tim? After a moment, Old Tim appears in the doorway, wringing knit cap in his hands. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I... Can I t-t-talk to you? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Come on in.  I was just packing. Pete stands, gestures Old Tim to the chair, as he sits on bed. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, sit. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. He sits.  Pause. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll come back, you know.  They'll all c-c-come back. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers?  I don't know... OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will.  They w-w-will. Pete turns to Old Tim, fixes him in the eye. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tim, I have to tell you something. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about me. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Pause, as Pete gathers courage and tries to find the word PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm not Luke.  Luke is dead.  He died in the war.  He's not coming back, and I'm not him.  I don't even belong here.  This whole thing started out as an accident, and that's all it is.  An accident. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name isn't Luke.  It's Peter.  Peter Appleton. Old Tim stands and looks askance at Pete. Pause. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think I didn't kn-kn-know that? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I thought you... OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know more than you give me c-c- credit, that's for sure.  Don't you see, it don't m-m-matter who you are?  All that matters is what you g-g-gave us.  And you can't take that away now.  You're wrong, Peter Appleton.  You do belong here. He leans down to Pete. OLD TIM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hafta give us back the B-B- Bijou. Old Tim straightens up, nods at Pete.  Then, silently, he picks up Cat and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete and Adele walk slowly down the platform toward the waiting train. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got everything? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Except a chance in hell of coming out of this intact. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be fine.  No matter what Leo Kubelsky says, you've got a hundred and seventy-five years of American law on your side.  Don't forget that. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish you were coming with me. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who's gonna run the projector until you get back?  Mrs. Terwilliger? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we could train Cat to run the projector.  You know, a system of scratching posts, and gears, and levers... They both smile as the train's HORN blows. CONDUCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Board! Pete picks up his suitcase and they walk toward the passe compartment. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you bring along something to read? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn... Adele pulls a pocket-sized leather-bound book out of her purse and hands it to Pete. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so.  Here.  This is mine, you can borrow it.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOOK
dialogues.text: Well-worn and scuffed, nevertheless the title is clear:

dialogues.speaker: CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES
dialogues.text: ANNOTATED EDITION

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete looks at the book, then at Adele. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly light reading, I know.  Believe it or not, I've read this since high school, and it got me all the way through law school.  Besides, there's something in there that'll help you.  You won't have to get very far, it's near the beginning. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearly touched) Delly... thanks, thank you.  I'll take good care of this. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember two things.  First, the law is a living thing.  It made us free and it keeps us free.  Sometimes it gets twisted around by people for their own purposes.  Sometimes it makes mistakes, sometimes big mistakes.  But in the end, the law prevails for the just.  Sometimes, it takes a while. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  What's the second thing? She thinks for a moment.  She needs the right words. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be here... if you come back. The train pulls out.  Adele and Pete exchange waves as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House Committee on Un-American Activities has effecti taken over the Grand Ballroom of this magnificent hotel, the joint is packed to the rafters.  Members of the AUDIE crane their necks to see out into the hallway, from where witnesses will be entering. The COMMITTEE MEMBERS are seated at their dais, brightly by the dozens of newsreel and TV lights.  Elvin Clyde is seated at the far right.  Dead center of the dais is the Chairman, CONGRESSMAN T. JOHNSTON DOYLE of Wisconsin, a husky man in his late 50s.  He SLAMS his gavel down sever times and the room goes quiet -- the talking stops, and t cameras start whirring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele's in a chair, eyes glues to the TV set.  Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim sit on the couch, watching attentively. Doc Lardner's in a straight-backed chair at a jaunty angl the set, holding the rabbit ears uncomfortably high aloft ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfect, Dad. DOYLE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The committee and the chamber will come to order. Lardner forces a smile at Mrs. Terwilliger and Old Tim. LARDNER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweating and wincing) This television's a grand little invention, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agenda for this morning's special session of the House Committee on Un-American Activities shows a number of witnesses, and I'd like to admonish those that are here to view the testimony of our first witness to keep order at all times, or this chamber will be closed.  I'm referring especially to the ladies and gentlemen of the press.  I hope that's clear. Beat.  Doyle scans the room.  He clearly means business. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Peter Appleton. All eyes and cameras swing toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: ON PETE
dialogues.text: As he enters the chamber, dozens of FLASHBULBS fire as ev eye and every camera follows him silently to his seat.  A sits, he glances behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Kubelsky is sitting in the front row of spectators. smiles and nods at Pete. Pete doesn't acknowledge him, and turns back. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness will please stand and raise his right hand. Pete does as instructed. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you swear that the testimony you are about to give before this committee of the United States House of Representatives will be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you god? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seated and state your full name and place of residence for the record. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Kenneth Appleton.  Hollywood, California. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chair notes that you are appearing without the benefit of counsel today, Mr. Appleton.  We certainly hope this means that you intend to be fully forthcoming with this committee? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faint smile) I'll do my best, Mr. Chairman. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, we're informed that you have a statement you'd like to read, is that correct? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (innocently) A statement? Doyle and Clyde exchange glances. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  A prepared statement. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... no.  I don't have a statement at this time. Pete turns in his chair and winks at Leo.  Leo rolls his and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele breathes a sigh of relief. MRS. TERWILLIGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's doing very well, so far. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They haven't called out the dogs yet. DOYLE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well then, the questions will be asked by the Majority Counsel, Mr. Clyde. The TV shot swings to see Elvin Clyde.  He puts on his glasses and fixes Pete with an oily grin. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke too soon. CLYDE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you Mr. Chairman, and thank you Mr. Appleton, for appearing today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, you mention that your home is Hollywood, California.  But isn't it true that for the last several months, you've made your home in a town called Lawson, California? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, that is true. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, do you know an "Albert Lucas Trumbo?" PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke Trumbo?  We never met.  But I'd like to think I know him. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that because you were masquerading as Luke Trumbo while you were in Lawson? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clyde you're twisting things around.  I wasn't masquerading.  Luke Trumbo... Luke was a good man who gave his life for his country.  I just... happen to look a little bit like him.  That's all. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (referring to notes) Yes, I see that Private Trumbo was reported missing in action and is presumed dead.  I also see that you were posted stateside during the war.  Fort Dix? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sure we're all glad to see you came through it all right. A few spectators titter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mabel and Bob listen to the hearing on a radio in the pac diner. CLYDE (ON RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I see that you've been running a movie theater in Lawson called "The Bijou," is that also true? PETE (ON RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes sir.  But I didn't go to Lawson to run The Bijou, that was... that was something that just happened.  You see, I was involved in an accident in Lawson, and I spent some time recovering there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde holds up copies of the Los Angeles Examiner and Los Angeles Times with Pete's picture on the front page. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who reads the newspaper is quite familiar with your... "accident," Mr. Appleton.  An accident which, conveniently, came hard upon your dismissal from United Pictures.  Tell us, this "accident" of yours, are we given to understand that it affected your memory? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what is the state of your memory now? Beat.  Pete smiles. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, what was the question? The audience LAUGHS.  Clyde nods at Pete, forces a tight smile. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... appreciate... your little note of levity, Mr. Appleton, but this is a very serious matter, and it merits your fullest attention. (back to business) That state of your memory now, Mr. Appleton?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avery Wyatt listens to the hearing on a store radio.  Spe comes around the paint aisle, wiping his hands on his apr He moves to the radio and listens solemnly. PETE (ON RADIO)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, are you referring to the fact that I was suffering from amnesia, and I've since recovered my memory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) I'm interested in knowing if you remember things you did in your past, or if they've been conveniently "blotted out" as a result of your "accident." PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Mr. Clyde, I remember everything. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Good. (holds up a piece of paper) Now, I hold in my hand a photostatic copy of the attendance roster for the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club" of the University of California, Los Angeles, dated October 11, 1935.  A copy of this paper is before you, Mr. Appleton.  Do you recognize it? Pete looks on the table and finds the roster.  He's surpr to see it. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... yes, I do. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Referring to line thirty-seven of the document, does your printed name and signature appear there? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it does. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, please tell this committee what was the nature and purpose of the "Bread Instead of Bullets Club?" PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clyde, do you want to know what I knew then, or do you want to know what I know now?  They're two different things? CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start with what you knew then. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd direct the attention of counsel and committee to line thirty-six of the document, and the name printed and signed there. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see it.  For the record, it reads "Lucille Angstrom."  What's the point of this? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's what I knew then.  Or who I knew, I should say.  You see, I was trying to court Miss Angstrom.  I went to the meeting to impress her. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning) Are you asking this committee to believe that you attended a meeting of a communist party front organization in order to impress a girl? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slyly) Well, if you'd seen Miss Angstrom... The audience LAUGHS.  Doyle BANGS his gavel. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You asked for the truth.  That's the truth.  I had no idea what the meeting was about.  I just sat through it so I could be near her.  I'm sure even a Majority Counsel like yourself is familiar with the concept of impressing a girl. The audience LAUGHS.  Clyde shoots a look at Doyle, who B his gavel. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chamber will come to order. Clyde shuffles some papers and looks back at Pete. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Appleton.  That was what you knew then.  What do you know now? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes a deep breath) Well, I know that I lost my job because of one meeting I went to when I was a kid in college.  I know that I've been branded a communist, which I'm not, but even if I was, it shouldn't matter, or what do we have a Bill Of Rights for? CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman, the witness is being non-responsive... A few members of the audience APPLAUD.  As Pete speaks, t numbers grow. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (passionately) I know that a lot of good, honest, decent people, people that I consider my true friends, feel betrayed by me, not because of who and what I am, but because of what you say I am!  I know that I... Doyle BANGS his gavel several times.  Pete stops and the falls quiet. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (emphatically) Mr. Appleton, you will respond to the questions of this committee without elaboration or speechmaking, or the chair will find you in Contempt Of Congress.  You will not be warned again, is that clear? (he lets this sink in, then) Continue, Mr. Clyde. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking down at his desk) Mr. Appleton... Clyde takes a long pause for effect, then looks up at Pet CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you now, or have you ever been, a member of the communist party? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the roster) Are you refuting this evidence and your previous testimony? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not refuting anything. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet you're contradicting yourself.  You earlier testified that you attended a meeting of a communist party-run organization, yet you just said, under oath, that you were not now -- nor ever -- a member of the communist party. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a contradiction at all, sir.  I went to the meeting, but I didn't go as a member. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, as what did you go? Beat.  Pete smiles. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little hesitant to say. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness need not be hesitant to say anything before this committee, as long as it's the truth. Pete shifts in his chair, then leans into the microphone. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I went as... a horny young man. The chamber erupts in LAUGHTER.  Even the other COMMITTEE MEMBERS are laughing, except Clyde and Doyle, who BANGS h gavel vigorously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff Eldridge and Daley Thornhill listen to the hearin the radio.  They are both laughing at Pete's last comment ELDRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, he don't wanna spar with these boys.  They'll eat him alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room settles.  Doyle wags his finger accusingly at Pe DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) Mr. Appleton, you are making light of a legally constituted committee of the United States Congress.  Believe you me, you do not want to incur our wrath. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) I'm sorry, sir, I have no intention of making light of this committee.  And I have no intention of incurring your wrath, Mr. Chairman.  I have a few friends who have already incurred your wrath.  They've sent me letters from jail. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Mr. Chairman!  Mr. Chairman, the witness is making another speech.  I would ask that Mr. Appleton be admonished... DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indifferent) Mr. Appleton, there is no question before you at this time, but I'm sure Mr. Clyde has plenty more prepared, and if you'd like to either answer them or plead the Fifth Amendment, we can at least get on with the business of this committee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adele moves to within inches of the TV screen. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them Pete.  Tell them... PETE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrestling with this) Mr. Chairman, as I understand it, the Fifth Amendment pertains to self-incrimination, and I can't incriminate myself because I've done nothing wrong.  Besides, incrimination is why you have Mr. Clyde working for you. CLYDE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clyde is still protesting, but Doyle waves him off. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, Mr. Appleton, just what is your intention? Pete's sweating under the lights.  He's bluffed his last bluff, and he's on the ropes.  He reaches into his pocket and takes out the prepared statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETE (ON TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... Mr. Chairman, I have a prepared statement I'd like to read...

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: Her hand goes to her mouth. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Pete.  No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Mr. Appleton. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly reading) "I, Peter Appleton, do hereby..." He stops suddenly.  Pause. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton?  Mr. Appleton? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I need a drink of water. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, son. Pete fills a glass from the pitcher.  Nervously, he spill bit, and is splashes onto his coat.  As some of the spectators chuckle, Pete brushes the water off.  He reach into his pocket, and pulls out Adele's copy of the constitution.  The cover is wet.  He wipes it off and set down on the table. He takes a sip of water.  Looks at the book.  Picks it up Pete's terrified, but in control.  He speaks slowly -- he making this up and thinking it out as he goes. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman... there's... another Amendment... that I'd like to invoke at this time, but it's not the Fifth Amendment.  I wonder if you're familiar with it. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Appleton, you will... He opens the book and reads, tentatively at first. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances." Pause.  Silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: She's smiling at the TV.  Her eyes are filled with tears.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: He looks up at Chairman Doyle.  Now fully confident. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the First Amendment, Mr. Chairman.  It's the backbone of this nation.  It's everything that gives us the potential to be right and good and just -- if only we'd live up to that potential.  It's what gives me the right to sit in this chair and say my piece before this committee without fear.  It's the most important part of the contract that every citizen has with this country.  And even though this contract... (he holds up the book) ... the Constitution and the Bill of Rights -- even though they're just pieces of paper with signatures on them -- they're the only contracts we have that are most definitely not subject to renegotiation.  Not by you, Mr. Chairman, not by you, Mr. Clyde, not by any member of this committee -- or anyone else -- ever. Pin-drop silence in the room.  Pete scans the faces of th panel.  All betray anger.

dialogues.speaker: ON LEO
dialogues.text: He can't help but smile and nod appreciatively. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when you get right down to it, that's really all I have to say to this committee.  Good morning. And with that, Pete closes the book, picks up the prepare statement, rips it up, pushes back his chair, stands and walks toward the door.  The cameras swing with him, and FLASHBULBS fire like machine guns.  Doyle BANGS his gavel insistently. DOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The witness will resume his seat!  Did you hear me?!  You are not excused, Mr. Appleton! And then, slowly, APPLAUSE builds in the chamber, reachin crescendo as Pete reaches the door and exits. CLYDE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chairman!  Mr. Chairman...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pete exits the hotel, a DOZEN REPORTERS AND PHOTOGRAPH have him completely surrounded.  FLASHBULBS pop.  He's ta aback, flustered. FIRST REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Pete) There he is! SECOND REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete!  Are you going back to writing pictures? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... THIRD REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You a commie, Pete? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not... SECOND REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the girl, Pete?  You gonna marry her?  Is she coming to Hollywood, or are you... PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, fellas, I don't have anything to say... Pete is trapped in the crowd, when he feels a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: spins him around, and pushes him through the crowd toward curb. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kid. At the curb is a black Cadillac limousine.  Leo hauls ope the back door and pushes Pete in, before climbing in hims The limo drives away, as the reporters give chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo and Pete sit side-by-side in silence for a moment.  L breaks it. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quite a show you gave them today.  We shoulda sold tickets. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sorry for what I said. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not, why should you be sorry?  You're the new Peter Appleton.  You exercised your rights as a solid citizen, first amendment, freedom of speech, all that.  Very noble. They sit in silence again for a moment until Leo reaches his pocket and withdraws a gold cigarette case, which he opens and offers to Pete. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. Leo takes one for himself and lights up.  Pete takes off hat and nervously scratches his head. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When'd you quit smoking? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke didn't smoke. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see.  But you're not Luke.  You're Peter Appleton, the picture writer. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Not any more. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you were in there, you saw what I did.  You think they're gonna let me write pictures?  Hell, they're probably gonna throw my ass in jail. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smile) Not at all. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I don't even know if I want to write anymore. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snickering) What, you're going to go back to that hick town and run the projector and marry the doctor's daughter? But before Pete can answer... LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, I'm an agent.  I buy lunches and get deals made for guys like you.  That's what I do.  You're a writer.  You write pictures.  That's what you do.  And trust me, you'll be back doing it again tomorrow morning. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, you gave them what they wanted.  This committee, it feeds on names.  The more names, the better.  But for some high-profile witnesses, like yourself, any name will do. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, I didn't give them the names.  I wouldn't do that. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, all of a sudden, "Lucille Angstrom" isn't a name? Pete freezes.  He slowly turns to Leo. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily) Her name was right there in front of them.  They gave it to me, I didn't give it to them. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not what they think. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, she was... she was a girl I knew in college... LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should keep track of your old school chums.  Turns out she eventually joined the communist party. (takes a puff) On top of which, she's Lucy Angstrom Hirschfeld now, and she happens to be a writer for "Studio One" on CBS. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realization dawning) Oh god, oh, god, no, I... LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, our lawyers had a talk with the Committee's lawyers.  That Elvin Clyde fella won't be too happy about it, but we cut a deal.  They cleared you -- and they're gonna thank you publicly for your testimony purging yourself. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank me publicly?  For what?  For ruining this woman's life? LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Climb down off your cross.  They already knew about her. (off his look) She was subpoenaed six months ago!  Who the hell do you think named you? Pete is dumbstruck.  He slumps in his seat, ashen. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he couldn't be happier) All of which means... "Ashes To Ashes" is gonna be made, and you've got your job back. (takes a puff) Congratulations, kid. Pete's breathing shallowly, on the verge of tears or screaming -- or both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limo pulls up, and Leo opens the door.  Pete vacantly grabs his suitcase and gets out.  Leo shuts the door and calls after him, waving Pete's hat. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter!  Your hat! Pete comes back and takes his hat.  Leo grabs his hand. LEO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was lookin' out for you all the time, kid.  You did good.  I'm real proud of you. (to the driver) Okay, let's go. (to Pete) Get some rest, kid! As the limo pulls away, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, revealing the Super, followed by a sullen Pete, carrying his suitcases and hat.  He sets them down goes to the coffee table, where his boxes of belongings f the studio have been gathering dust these last three mont SUPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him a key) Here's a new key for ya.  That Mr. Kubelsky, he's got you paid up through this month.  You got one swell friend there. The Super moves to the door and turns back. SUPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to have you back, Pete. He exits as Pete reaches into one of the boxes and pulls the tin-toy fire truck.  Distractedly, Pete puts the toy in the box and replies too late: PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks... He sets his suitcase down and takes off his coat.  As he does, Adele's copy of the Constitution slips out of his c pocket and falls open to the floor. Pete picks it up and absently turns it over -- and the inscription inside the front cover catches his eye: TO DELLY,

dialogues.speaker: THE GIRL WITH ALL THE ANSWERS.
dialogues.text: LOVE, LUKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete closes the book.  He thinks for a moment, then glanc over at the phone.  He picks it up and dials "0." PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Western Union, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our view of the moving train is from outside, as it speed the spectacular coastline north of Santa Barbara.  Lookin into one of the train's windows, we SEE Pete sitting, sta out at the passing scenery. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Adele, on my way back to Lawson STOP.  That is, if they'll have me STOP.  Train arrives four p.m. STOP.  Hope you can be there STOP.  Pete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train is just pulling in to Lawson.  As it SHUDDERS t halt, the door of the passenger compartment opens and Pet steps out -- looks -- and his jaw drops open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ENTIRE TOWN has turned out.  They're all there, smili broadly.  A large, hand-lettered banner reads: WELCOME HOME PETE! LAWSON'S FAVORITE SON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CHEER goes up from the crowd, breaking the silence.  Pe descends from the train and moves into the throng.  The f two people he encounters are Bob Leffert and Mabel Lanier bob sticks out his good hand and Pete takes it, both smil as they shake hands vigorously. BOB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke... um, I mean, Pete, if it weren't for you, I wouldn't have had the nerve to ask this fine woman to marry me. Mabel's mouth drops open. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, congratulations!  When'd you ask her? MABEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy moley!  Just now! (to Bob) Yes, Bob!  Yes! As Mabel kisses Bob for all she's worth, Pete continues i the crowd, where he's kissed, embraced, patted on the bac

dialogues.speaker: ADELE
dialogues.text: is at the back of the crowd, working her way to the front She rushes into Pete's arms, and they kiss.  Another CHEE goes up. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you got the telegram. ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete, I'm so sorry about what they did to you.  I didn't think you'd come back, I thought you'd want to write again... PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dell, I can't write unless I'm happy, and I can't be happy unless I'm here -- and with you. (grabs her shoulders) This is me, Delly.  Pete Appleton.  And I love you! ADELE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tears in her eyes) And (hic!) I love you, Pete! They kiss again.  Pete pulls away and looks at his watch. PETE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) C'mon, Dell, we gotta go.  Showtime in fifteen minutes. The train whistle BLOWS as it slowly pulls out of the station. PETE'S NARRATION (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Happily ever after" is a relative term, folks.  My world is much smaller now, and my dreams are very different than they were.  But I have something now that I never had before: I have the magic.  And it's for sale at the Bijou, every day of the year.  All you need is the price of a ticket. We BOOM UP to see Pete and Adele moving into and being enveloped by the crowd.
